replies.msg:
Rafael Hernández

Easily, just easily, the worst night I will ever have as a football fan in my life. Three consecutive Champions Leagues by Real Madrid, four in five years, Portugal winning the Euros and now the most embarrassing match in Barcelona’s history.

I really wished this season would’ve proven me wrong for good, shut me up forever about being realistic, and wanting Messi to leave two years ago. I really tried to wish for the best and be hopeful for good, to choose the delusional route. To not think, to be an idiot.

If Valverde doesn’t get sacked tonight before he fucking arrives back at Barcelona, it’s better to simply stop supporting the club altogether. If Roma wasn’t enough, the biggest European disgrace in the club’s history, tonight just became the worst match in the club’s history.

Roma didn’t bother me for a second, I cared about the defeat vs Levante that stopped an undefeated league. But tonight was like dying, or really, like something that would never happen even in the worst nightmarish timeline. But it did.

It’s been a while, but it’s the first time I cry watching football since Chelsea 2012. However, that night was just knowing Barcelona tried its best and it wasn’t enough, that’s completely fine.

Tonight is all about hate, rage, resignation, defeat, despair and emptiness. This isn’t heartbreak, this is complete annihilation. I can’t really describe the feeling.

Maybe Barcelona died with Johan Cruyff, or when Guardiola left, maybe both times. This team doesn’t represent any ideals or values, or a desire to play beautiful football, it’s a complete farce.

What do you even tell Messi after a night like this? The man has been carrying the club for years on his back, supporting mediocre coaches one after another, doing everything he could, yet everyone let him down, again.

To my fellow Barcelona fans, I wish you all a happy ten year anniversary of the first treble. Everything that begun that day ended tonight.

quote.msg:
Rafael Hernández

Easily, just easily, the worst night I will ever have as a football fan in my life. Three consecutive Champions Leagues by Real Madrid, four in five years, Portugal winning the Euros and now the most embarrassing match in Barcelona’s history.

I really wished this season would’ve proven me wrong for good, shut me up forever about being realistic, and wanting Messi to leave two years ago. I really tried to wish for the best and be hopeful for good, to choose the delusional route. To not think, to be an idiot.

If Valverde doesn’t get sacked tonight before he fucking arrives back at Barcelona, it’s better to simply stop supporting the club altogether. If Roma wasn’t enough, the biggest European disgrace in the club’s history, tonight just became the worst match in the club’s history.

Roma didn’t bother me for a second, I cared about the defeat vs Levante that stopped an undefeated league. But tonight was like dying, or really, like something that would never happen even in the worst nightmarish timeline. But it did.

It’s been a while, but it’s the first time I cry watching football since Chelsea 2012. However, that night was just knowing Barcelona tried its best and it wasn’t enough, that’s completely fine.

Tonight is all about hate, rage, resignation, defeat, despair and emptiness. This isn’t heartbreak, this is complete annihilation. I can’t really describe the feeling.

Maybe Barcelona died with Johan Cruyff, or when Guardiola left, maybe both times. This team doesn’t represent any ideals or values, or a desire to play beautiful football, it’s a complete farce.

What do you even tell Messi after a night like this? The man has been carrying the club for years on his back, supporting mediocre coaches one after another, doing everything he could, yet everyone let him down, again.

To my fellow Barcelona fans, I wish you all a happy ten year anniversary of the first treble. Everything that begun that day ended tonight.

We can't make the same mistake two years in a row – Suarez laments Barca collapse
An apologetic and hurt Luis Suarez said Barcelona have a lot to evaluate and think about after their sensational collapse at the hands of Liverpool in the Champions League semi-finals.

A 3-0 first-leg deficit was incredibly erased by Jurgen Klopp's Liverpool, who stunned LaLiga champions Barca 4-0 at Anfield on Tuesday.

Braces from Divock Origi and Georginio Wijnaldum sent last season's runners-up Liverpool through to the Madrid decider on June 1 as Barca were left licking their wounds.

In 2017-18, Barca saw a 4-1 opening-leg advantage wiped out by Roma, who won the return fixture 3-0 in the Italian capital to progress to the semis.

Reflecting on Barca's latest collapse, star forward Suarez said: "We have to do a lot of self-criticism, it's the second time the same happens to us.

"We cannot make these mistakes two years in a row, we have to reproach ourselves for what we are doing wrong. There's a lot to evaluate and think about."

"We are very sad, hurt, we are human beings, we feel the pain, the frustration, we have to do self-criticism, put our chest for the bullets of what is coming now," he continued.

Ernesto Valverde has led Barca to back-to-back LaLiga titles but Barca's European catastrophe has raised doubts over the head coach.

"We are the ones who play, the coach made the tactics that he made in the first leg," Suarez said. "We, the players, have to be self-aware, we are the ones who play.

"We have to apologise for the attitude, we were not a team. To our families, our children, our fans, we have to ask their forgiveness, it cannot be that in a minute we concede two goals.

"In the fourth goal we looked like youngsters. We have to understand all the criticisms that are going to rain on us."

quote.msg: å’é«˜ä¼°è¯ç‹—ï¼Ÿ ä½¢éƒ½ä¿‚60mimsè½‰442 æ‰“4é˜²ä¸­æ­»å®ˆ åªè¦å°æ–¹å¤ å£“è¿« å·´å¡å°±æ‰“å””è¿”å‡ºå» ç›´è‡³æ¯”äººå±ˆæ­»

replies.msg:
Valverde, whose team gave up a 4-1 first-leg lead against Roma in the quarter-finals last season, refused to make excuses after the extraordinary exit.

"They started very aggressive, very high – what we expected. They made the first goal but we managed to settle in," he told a news conference.

"In the first half, we had options to score. The second goal hurt us because the third one followed.

"Well, very aggressive and we don't change the possibilities. The score is huge, but if you lose 4-0 there are no excuses. They were better and you have to accept it."

"Everything we do and everything we play is always to please the fans, so that they are proud of the players.

"In this football, what happens is that everyone expects to win always and there are times when we lose.

"When we lose, we have had to do it painfully. We have not lost until now and we are out. In this story, we are all together."


Asked for his message to the fans, he said: "We are very sorry.
